built with pdoc

sain

sain is a set of minimal abstraction that brings Rust's ecosystem to Python. It offers a few of the core Rust features like Vec<T> and Result<T, E> and more. See the equivalent type section below.

Equivalent types
  • Option<T> -> Option[T] | Some[T]
  • Result<T, E> -> Result[T, E]
  • Error -> Error
  • Vec<T> -> Vec[T]
  • Default<T> -> Default[T]
  • Iter<Item> -> Iter[Item]
  • Box<T> -> Box[T], not a heap box.
  • cell::Cell<T> -> Cell[T], slightly different.
  • cell::RefCell<T> -> RefCell[T], slightly different.
  • sync::LazyLock<T> -> Lazy[T]
  • sync::OnceLock<T> -> Once[T]
Equivalent macros

As decorators.

  • cfg!() -> sain.cfg
  • todo!() -> sain.todo. This is not a decorator.
  • deprecated!() -> sain.deprecated
  • unimplemented!() -> sain.unimplemented
  • #[cfg_attr] -> sain.cfg_attr
  • #[doc()] -> sain.doc()

 31"""sain is a set of minimal abstraction that brings Rust's ecosystem to Python.
 32It offers a few of the core Rust features like `Vec<T>` and `Result<T, E>` and more.
 33See the equivalent type section below.
 34
 35Equivalent types
 36----------------
 37- `Option<T>` -> `Option[T]` | `Some[T]`
 38- `Result<T, E>` -> `Result[T, E]`
 39- `Error` -> `Error`
 40- `Vec<T>` -> `Vec[T]`
 41- `Default<T>` -> `Default[T]`
 42- `Iter<Item>` -> `Iter[Item]`
 43- `Box<T>` -> `Box[T]`, not a heap box.
 44- `cell::Cell<T>` -> `Cell[T]`, slightly different.
 45- `cell::RefCell<T>` -> `RefCell[T]`, slightly different.
 46- `sync::LazyLock<T>` -> `Lazy[T]`
 47- `sync::OnceLock<T>` -> `Once[T]`
 48
 49Equivalent macros
 50-----------------
 51As decorators.
 52
 53- `cfg!()` -> `sain.cfg`
 54- `todo!()` -> `sain.todo`. This is not a decorator.
 55- `deprecated!()` -> `sain.deprecated`
 56- `unimplemented!()` -> `sain.unimplemented`
 57- `#[cfg_attr]` -> `sain.cfg_attr`
 58- `#[doc()]` -> `sain.doc()`
 59"""

def cfg( target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'unix', 'windows']] = None, requires: str | None = None, python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> bool: 
186def cfg(
187    target_os: System | None = None,
188    requires: str | None = None,
189    python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None,
190    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
191    impl: Python | None = None,
192) -> bool:
193    """A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns `True`.
194
195    .. warning::
196        The `requires` parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release.
197        Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.
198
199    The difference between this function and `cfg_attr` is that this function will not raise an exception.
200    Instead it will return `False` if any of the attributes fails.
201
202    Example
203    -------
204    ```py
205    import sain
206
207    if sain.cfg(target_os="windows"):
208        print("Windows")
209    elif sain.cfg(target_os="linux"):
210        print("Linux")
211    else:
212        print("Something else")
213    ```
214
215    Parameters
216    ----------
217    requires : `str | None`
218        A required module to run the object.
219    target_os : `str | None`
220        The targeted operating system thats required for the object to be ran.
221    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
222        The targeted Python version thats required for the object to be ran. Format must be `(3, 9, 5)``
223    target_arch : `str | None`
224        The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object to be ran.
225    impl : `str | None`
226        The Python implementation thats required for the object to be ran.
227
228    Returns
229    -------
230    `bool`
231        The condition that was checked.
232    """
233    checker = _AttrCheck(
234        lambda: None,
235        no_raise=True,
236        requires=requires,
237        target_os=target_os,
238        python_version=python_version,
239        target_arch=target_arch,
240        impl=impl,
241    )
242    return checker.internal_check()

A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns True.

The requires parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release. Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.

The difference between this function and cfg_attr is that this function will not raise an exception. Instead it will return False if any of the attributes fails.

Example
import sain

if sain.cfg(target_os="windows"):
    print("Windows")
elif sain.cfg(target_os="linux"):
    print("Linux")
else:
    print("Something else")
Parameters
  • requires (str | None): A required module to run the object.
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system thats required for the object to be ran.
  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version thats required for the object to be ran. Format must be `(3, 9, 5)``
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object to be ran.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation thats required for the object to be ran.
Returns
  • bool: The condition that was checked.
def cfg_attr( *, requires: str | None = None, target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'unix', 'windows']] = None, python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> collections.abc.Callable[[~F], ~F]: 
102def cfg_attr(
103    *,
104    requires: str | None = None,
105    target_os: System | None = None,
106    python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None,
107    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
108    impl: Python | None = None,
109) -> collections.Callable[[F], F]:
110    """Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.
111
112    If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns `False`,
113    `RuntimeError` will be raised and the object will not run.
114
115    .. warning::
116        The `requires` parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation
117        and will be removed in a future release.
118        Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.
119
120    Example
121    -------
122    ```py
123    import sain
124
125    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
126    def windows_only():
127        # Do stuff with Windows's API.
128        ...
129
130    # Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
131    # when creating the instance.
132    @sain.cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
133    class Zoo:
134        @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
135        def bark(self) -> None:
136            windows_only()  # RuntimeError("Windows OS only!)
137
138    # An instance will not be created if raised.
139    zoo = Zoo()
140    # RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
141    zoo.bark()
142    # Whats zoo??
143    ```
144
145    Parameters
146    ----------
147    requires : `str | None`
148        A required module to run the object.
149    target_os : `str | None`
150        The targeted operating system thats required for the object.
151    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
152        The targeted Python version thats required for the object. Format must be `(3, 9, 5)`.
153    target_arch : `str | None`
154        The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object.
155    impl : `str | None`
156        The Python implementation thats required for the object.
157
158    Raises
159    ------
160    `RuntimeError`
161        This fails if any of the attributes returns `False`. `required_modules` is not included.
162    `ModuleNotFoundError`
163        If the module check fails. i.e., if `required_modules` was provided and it returns `False`.
164    `ValueError`
165        If the passed Python implementation is unknown.
166    """
167
168    def decorator(callback: F) -> F:
169        @functools.wraps(callback)
170        def wrapper(*args: typing.Any, **kwargs: typing.Any) -> F:
171            checker = _AttrCheck(
172                callback,
173                requires=requires,
174                target_os=target_os,
175                python_version=python_version,
176                target_arch=target_arch,
177                impl=impl,
178            )
179            return checker(*args, **kwargs)
180
181        return typing.cast(F, wrapper)
182
183    return decorator

Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.

If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns False, RuntimeError will be raised and the object will not run.

The requires parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release. Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.

Example
import sain

@sain.cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
def windows_only():
    # Do stuff with Windows's API.
    ...

# Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
# when creating the instance.
@sain.cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
class Zoo:
    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
    def bark(self) -> None:
        windows_only()  # RuntimeError("Windows OS only!)

# An instance will not be created if raised.
zoo = Zoo()
# RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
zoo.bark()
# Whats zoo??
Parameters
  • requires (str | None): A required module to run the object.
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system thats required for the object.
  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version thats required for the object. Format must be (3, 9, 5).
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation thats required for the object.
Raises
  • RuntimeError: This fails if any of the attributes returns False. required_modules is not included.
  • ModuleNotFoundError: If the module check fails. i.e., if required_modules was provided and it returns False.
  • ValueError: If the passed Python implementation is unknown.
@typing.runtime_checkable
class Default(typing.Protocol[+_T_co]): 
57@typing.runtime_checkable
58class Default(typing.Protocol[_T_co]):
59    """An interface for an object that has a default value.
60
61    Example
62    -------
63    ```py
64    from sain import Default
65
66    class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):
67
68        @staticmethod
69        def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
70            return {}
71
72    cache = Cache.default()
73    print(cache)
74    assert isinstance(cache, Default)
75    # {}
76    ```
77    """
78
79    __slots__ = ()
80
81    @staticmethod
82    def default() -> _T_co:
83        """Return the default value of the object."""
84        raise NotImplementedError

An interface for an object that has a default value.

Example
from sain import Default

class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):

    @staticmethod
    def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
        return {}

cache = Cache.default()
print(cache)
assert isinstance(cache, Default)
# {}
Default(*args, **kwargs) 
1430def _no_init_or_replace_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
1431    cls = type(self)
1432
1433    if cls._is_protocol:
1434        raise TypeError('Protocols cannot be instantiated')
1435
1436    # Already using a custom `__init__`. No need to calculate correct
1437    # `__init__` to call. This can lead to RecursionError. See bpo-45121.
1438    if cls.__init__ is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1439        return
1440
1441    # Initially, `__init__` of a protocol subclass is set to `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1442    # The first instantiation of the subclass will call `_no_init_or_replace_init` which
1443    # searches for a proper new `__init__` in the MRO. The new `__init__`
1444    # replaces the subclass' old `__init__` (ie `_no_init_or_replace_init`). Subsequent
1445    # instantiation of the protocol subclass will thus use the new
1446    # `__init__` and no longer call `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1447    for base in cls.__mro__:
1448        init = base.__dict__.get('__init__', _no_init_or_replace_init)
1449        if init is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1450            cls.__init__ = init
1451            break
1452    else:
1453        # should not happen
1454        cls.__init__ = object.__init__
1455
1456    cls.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
@staticmethod
def default() -> +_T_co: 
81    @staticmethod
82    def default() -> _T_co:
83        """Return the default value of the object."""
84        raise NotImplementedError

Return the default value of the object.

@typing.final
class Some(typing.Generic[~T], sain.Default[NoneType]): 
 55@typing.final
 56class Some(typing.Generic[T], _default.Default[None]):
 57    """The `Option` type. An object that might be `T` or `None`.
 58
 59    It is a drop-in replacement for `typing.Optional[T]`, But has proper methods to handle the contained value.
 60
 61    Example
 62    -------
 63    ```py
 64    value = Some("Hello")
 65    print(value)
 66    # Some("Hello")
 67
 68    # This will unwrap the contained value as long as
 69    # it is not `None` otherwise this will raise an error.
 70    print(value.unwrap())
 71    # "Hello"
 72
 73    none_value = Some(None)
 74    while none_value.unwrap():
 75        # Never unreachable!
 76
 77    # Solving it with `unwrap_or` method to unwrap the value or return a default value.
 78    print(none_value.unwrap_or(10))
 79    # 10
 80    ```
 81    """
 82
 83    __slots__ = ("_value",)
 84
 85    def __init__(self, value: T | None, /) -> None:
 86        self._value = value
 87
 88    @staticmethod
 89    def default() -> None:
 90        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None`."""
 91        return None
 92
 93    # *- Reading the value -*
 94
 95    @property
 96    def read(self) -> T | None:
 97        """Read the contained value."""
 98        return self._value
 99
100    def unwrap(self) -> T:
101        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
102
103        Example
104        -------
105        ```py
106        value = Some(5)
107        print(value.unwrap())
108        # 5
109
110        value = Some(None)
111        print(value.unwrap())
112        # RuntimeError
113        ```
114
115        Raises
116        ------
117        `RuntimeError`
118            If the inner value is `None`.
119        """
120        if self._value is None:
121            raise RuntimeError(
122                f"Called `Option.unwrap()` on {type(self._value).__name__}."
123            ) from None
124
125        return self._value
126
127    def unwrap_or(self, default: T, /) -> T:
128        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or returning `default`.
129
130        Example
131        -------
132        ```py
133        value = Some(5)
134        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
135        # 5
136
137        # Type hint is required here.
138        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
139        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
140        # 10
141        ```
142        """
143        if self._value is None:
144            return default
145
146        return self._value
147
148    def unwrap_or_else(self, f: FnOnce[T], /) -> T:
149        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or calling `f` to get a default value.
150
151        Example
152        -------
153        ```py
154        value = Some(5)
155        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: 10))
156        # 5
157
158        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
159        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: True))
160        # True
161        ```
162        """
163        if self._value is None:
164            return f()
165
166        return self._value
167
168    @macros.unsafe
169    def unwrap_unchecked(self) -> T:
170        """Unwrap the inner value immediately returning it.
171
172        Example
173        -------
174        ```py
175        v: Option[float] = Some(1.2)
176        v.unwrap_unchecked() # 1.2
177
178        v: Option[float] = Some(None)
179        print(v.unwrap_unchecked()) # Undefined Behavior
180        ```
181        """
182        #! SAFETY: The caller guarantees that the value is not None.
183        return self._value  # type: ignore
184
185    def expect(self, message: str, /) -> T:
186        """Returns the contained value if it is not `None` otherwise raises a `RuntimeError`.
187
188        Example
189        -------
190        ```py
191        value = Some("Hello")
192
193        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
194        # "Hello"
195
196        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
197        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
198        # RuntimeError("Value is None")
199        ```
200        """
201        if self._value is None:
202            raise RuntimeError(message)
203
204        return self._value
205
206    # *- Functional operations -*
207    def map(self, f: Fn[T, U], /) -> Some[U]:
208        """Map the inner value to another type. Returning `Some(None)` if `T` is `None`.
209
210        Example
211        -------
212        ```py
213        value = Some(5.0)
214
215        print(value.map(lambda x: x * 2.0))
216        # Some(10.0)
217
218        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
219        print(value)
220        # Some(None)
221        ```
222        """
223        if self._value is None:
224            return nothing_unchecked()
225
226        return Some(f(self._value))
227
228    def map_or(self, default: U, f: Fn[T, U], /) -> U:
229        """Map the inner value to another type or return `default` if its `None`.
230
231        Example
232        -------
233        ```py
234        value: Option[float] = Some(5.0)
235
236        # map to int.
237        print(value.map_or(0, int))
238        # 6
239
240        value: Option[float] = Some(None)
241        print(value.map_or(0, int)
242        # 0
243        ```
244        """
245        if self._value is None:
246            return default
247
248        return f(self._value)
249
250    def map_or_else(self, default: FnOnce[U], f: Fn[T, U], /) -> U:
251        """Map the inner value to another type, or return `default()` if its `None`.
252
253        Example
254        -------
255        ```py
256        def default() -> int:
257            return sys.getsizeof(object())
258
259        value: Option[float] = Some(5.0)
260
261        # map to int.
262        print(value.map_or_else(default, int))
263        # 6
264
265        value: Option[float] = Some(None)
266        print(value.map_or_else(default, int)
267        # 28 <- size of object()
268        ```
269        """
270        if self._value is None:
271            return default()
272
273        return f(self._value)
274
275    def filter(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> Some[T]:
276        """Returns `Some(None)` if the contained value is `None`,
277
278        otherwise calls the predicate and returns `Some(T)` if the predicate returns `True`.
279
280        Example
281        -------
282        ```py
283        value = Some([1, 2, 3])
284
285        print(value.filter(lambda x: 1 in x))
286        # Some([1, 2, 3])
287
288        value: Option[int] = Some([1, 2, 3]) # or Some(None)
289        print(value.filter(lambda x: 1 not in x))
290        # None
291        ```
292        """
293        if (value := self._value) is not None:
294            if predicate(value):
295                return Some(value)
296
297        return nothing_unchecked()
298
299    # *- Inner operations *-
300
301    def take(self) -> None:
302        """Take the value from `Some` object setting it to `None`.
303
304        Example
305        -------
306        ```py
307        value = Some("Hi")
308        value = value.take()
309        print(value)
310        # None
311        ```
312        """
313        if self._value is None:
314            return
315
316        self._value = None
317
318    def replace(self, value: T) -> Some[T]:
319        """Replace the contained value with another value.
320
321        Example
322        -------
323        ```py
324        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
325        value = value.replace("Hello")
326        # Some("Hello")
327        ```
328        """
329        self._value = value
330        return self
331
332    def and_ok(self, optb: Some[T]) -> Some[T]:
333        """Returns `Some(None)` if either contained value is `None`,
334
335        Otherwise return `optb`.
336
337        Example
338        -------
339        ```py
340        x: Option[int] = Some(None)
341        y: Option[str] = Some("bye")
342        assert x.and_ok(y).is_none()
343
344        x: Option[int] = Some(10)
345        y: Option[str] = Some("bye")
346        assert value.and_ok(y) == Some("bye")
347        ```
348        """
349        if self._value is None or optb.is_none():
350            return nothing_unchecked()
351
352        return optb
353
354    def and_then(self, f: Fn[T, Some[T]]) -> Some[T]:
355        """Returns `Some(None)` if the contained value is `None`, otherwise call `f()`
356        on `T` and return `Option[T]` if it's value not `None`.
357
358        Example
359        -------
360        ```py
361        value = Some(5)
362        print(value.and_then(lambda x: Some(x * 2)))
363        # Some(10)
364
365        value: Option[int] = Some(10)
366        print(value.and_then(lambda x: Some(None)))
367        # Some(None)
368        ```
369        """
370        if self._value is None:
371            return nothing_unchecked()
372
373        return f(self._value)
374
375    # *- Builder methods *-
376
377    def iter(self) -> iter.Iter[T]:
378        """Returns an iterator over the contained value.
379
380        Example
381        -------
382        ```py
383        from sain import Some
384        value = Some("gg")
385        value.next() == Some("gg")
386
387        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
388        value.next().is_none()
389        ```
390        """
391        if self._value is None:
392            #! SAFETY: We know the value is None here.
393            return iter.empty()  # pyright: ignore
394
395        return iter.once(self._value)
396
397    def as_ref(self) -> Some[cell.Cell[T]]:
398        """Returns immutable `Some[sain.cell.Cell[T]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
399
400        Otherwise returns `Some(None)`.
401
402        Example
403        -------
404        ```py
405        value = Some(5).as_ref().unwrap()
406        value.object = 0 # FrozenError!
407
408        owned = value.object
409        print(owned) # 5
410
411        # Create a copy of object.
412        clone = value.copy()
413        clone = 0  # Thats fine.
414        print(clone == owned) # False, 0 != 5
415
416        # None object.
417        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
418        print(value.as_ref())
419        # Some(None)
420        ```
421
422        Raises
423        ------
424        `dataclasses.FrozenInstanceError`
425            When attempting to modify the contained value. Use `sain.AsRef.copy()` method to create a copy.
426
427            Or just use `.as_mut()` if you're dealing with mutable objects.
428        """
429        if self._value is not None:
430            return Some(cell.Cell(self._value))
431
432        # SAFETY: self._value is None.
433        return NOTHING  # pyright: ignore
434
435    def as_mut(self) -> Some[cell.RefCell[T]]:
436        """Returns mutable `Some[sain.cell.RefCell[T]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
437
438        Otherwise returns `Some(None)`.
439
440        Example
441        -------
442        ```py
443        value = Some(5).as_mut().unwrap()
444        value.object = 0
445        print(value) # Some(RefCell(0))
446
447        # None object.
448        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
449        print(value.as_mut())
450        # Some(None)
451        ```
452        """
453        if self._value is not None:
454            return Some(cell.RefCell(self._value))
455
456        # SAFETY: self._value is None.
457        return NOTHING  # pyright: ignore
458
459    # *- Boolean checks *-
460
461    def is_some(self) -> bool:
462        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None`, otherwise returns `False`.
463
464        Example
465        -------
466        ```py
467        value = Some(5)
468        print(value.is_some())
469        # True
470
471        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
472        print(value.is_some())
473        # False
474        ```
475        """
476        return self._value is not None
477
478    def is_some_and(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> bool:
479        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None` and
480        the predicate returns `True`, otherwise returns `False`.
481
482        Example
483        -------
484        ```py
485        value = Some(5)
486        print(value.is_some_and(lambda x: x > 3))
487        # True
488
489        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
490        print(value.is_some_and(lambda x: x > 3))
491        # False
492        ```
493        """
494        return self._value is not None and predicate(self._value)
495
496    def is_none(self) -> bool:
497        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `None`, otherwise returns `False`.
498
499        Example
500        -------
501        ```py
502        value = Some(5)
503        print(value.is_none())
504        # False
505
506        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
507        print(value.is_none())
508        # True
509        ```
510        """
511        return self._value is None
512
513    def __repr__(self) -> str:
514        return f"Some({self._value!r})"
515
516    __str__ = __repr__
517
518    def __invert__(self) -> T:
519        return self.unwrap()
520
521    def __or__(self, other: T) -> T:
522        return self.unwrap_or(other)
523
524    def __bool__(self) -> bool:
525        return self.is_some()

527    def __eq__(self, other: object) -> bool:
528        if not isinstance(other, Some):
529            return NotImplemented
530
531        return self._value == other._value  # pyright: ignore[reportUnknownVariableType, reportUnknownMemberType]
532
533    def __ne__(self, other: object) -> bool:
534        return not self.__eq__(other)

537        return hash(self._value)

The Option type. An object that might be T or None.

It is a drop-in replacement for typing.Optional[T], But has proper methods to handle the contained value.

Example
value = Some("Hello")
print(value)
# Some("Hello")

# This will unwrap the contained value as long as
# it is not `None` otherwise this will raise an error.
print(value.unwrap())
# "Hello"

none_value = Some(None)
while none_value.unwrap():
    # Never unreachable!

# Solving it with `unwrap_or` method to unwrap the value or return a default value.
print(none_value.unwrap_or(10))
# 10
Some(value: Optional[~T], /) 
85    def __init__(self, value: T | None, /) -> None:
86        self._value = value
@staticmethod
def default() -> None: 
88    @staticmethod
89    def default() -> None:
90        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None`."""
91        return None

Default value for Some. Returns None.

read: Optional[~T] 
95    @property
96    def read(self) -> T | None:
97        """Read the contained value."""
98        return self._value

Read the contained value.

def unwrap(self) -> ~T: 
100    def unwrap(self) -> T:
101        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
102
103        Example
104        -------
105        ```py
106        value = Some(5)
107        print(value.unwrap())
108        # 5
109
110        value = Some(None)
111        print(value.unwrap())
112        # RuntimeError
113        ```
114
115        Raises
116        ------
117        `RuntimeError`
118            If the inner value is `None`.
119        """
120        if self._value is None:
121            raise RuntimeError(
122                f"Called `Option.unwrap()` on {type(self._value).__name__}."
123            ) from None
124
125        return self._value

class Iter(collections.abc.Iterator[~Item], collections.abc.Iterable[~Item], sain.Default[ForwardRef('Iter[ty_ext.Never]')]): 
 61class Iter(
 62    collections.Iterator[Item],
 63    collections.Iterable[Item],
 64    _default.Default["Iter[ty_ext.Never]"],
 65):
 66    """a lazy, in-memory functional iterator.
 67
 68    This is similar to Rust `Iterator` trait which iterables can build
 69    from this via `.iter()` method.
 70
 71    Example
 72    -------
 73    ```py
 74    iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
 75    # Limit the results to 2.
 76    for item in iterator.take(2):
 77        print(item)
 78    # 1
 79    # 2
 80
 81    # Filter the results.
 82    for item in iterator.filter(lambda item: item > 1):
 83        print(item)
 84        print(iterator.count())
 85    # 2
 86    # 3
 87    # 3
 88
 89    # Indexing is supported.
 90    print(iterator[0])
 91    # 1
 92    ```
 93
 94    Parameters
 95    ----------
 96    items: `Iterable[Item]`
 97        The items to iterate over. This must be an iterable.
 98    """
 99
100    __slots__ = ("_items",)
101
102    def __init__(self, items: collections.Iterable[Item]) -> None:
103        self._items = iter(items)
104
105    ###################
106    # const functions #
107    ###################
108
109    @staticmethod
110    @typing.final
111    def default() -> Iter[ty_ext.Never]:
112        """Return the default iterator for this type. It returns an empty iterator.
113
114        Example
115        -------
116        ```py
117        it = Iter.default()
118        assert t.next().is_none()
119        ```
120        """
121        return empty()
122
123    @typing.overload
124    @typing.final
125    def collect(self) -> collections.Sequence[Item]: ...
126
127    @typing.overload
128    @typing.final
129    def collect(self, *, cast: _B) -> collections.Sequence[_B]: ...

131    @typing.final
132    def collect(
133        self, *, cast: _B | None = None
134    ) -> collections.Sequence[Item] | collections.Sequence[_B]:
135        """Collects all items in the iterator into an immutable sequence.
136
137        Example
138        -------
139        ```py
140        iterator = Iter(range(3))
141        iterator.collect()
142        # (0, 1, 2, 3)
143        iterator.collect(cast=str) # Map each element and collect it.
144        # ('0', '1', '2', '3')
145        ```
146
147        Parameters
148        ----------
149        cast: `T | None`
150            An optional type to cast the items into.
151            If not provided the items will be returned as it's original type.
152        """
153        if cast is not None:
154            return tuple(map(cast, self._items))
155
156        return tuple(self._items)
157
158    @typing.final
159    def to_vec(self) -> Vec[Item]:
160        """Convert this iterator into `Vec[T]`.
161
162        Example
163        -------
164        ```py
165        it = sain.iter.once(0)
166        vc = it.to_vec()
167
168        assert to_vec == [0]
169        ```
170        """
171        return Vec(self._items)
172
173    @typing.final
174    def copied(self) -> Iter[Item]:
175        """Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.
176
177        .. note::
178            If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use `by_ref` instead.
179
180        Example
181        -------
182        ```py
183        it = Iter([None, None, None])
184        copied = it.copied()
185        assert it.collect() == copied.collect()
186        ```
187        """
188        return Iter(copy.deepcopy(self._items))
189
190    @typing.final
191    def by_ref(self) -> Iter[Item]:
192        """Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.
193
194        Example
195        -------
196        ```py
197        it = Iter([None, None, None])
198        for ref in it.by_ref():
199            ...
200
201        # Original not consumed.
202        assert it.count() == 3
203        ```
204        """
205        return Iter(copy.copy(self._items))

207    @typing.final
208    def sink(self) -> None:
209        """Consume all elements from this iterator, flushing it into the sink.
210
211        Example
212        -------
213        ```py
214        it = Iter((1, 2, 3))
215        it.sink()
216        assert it.next().is_none()
217        ```
218        """
219        for _ in self._items:
220            pass

226    def next(self) -> Option[Item]:
227        """Returns the next item in the iterator, `Some(None)` if all items yielded.
228
229        Example
230        -------
231        ```py
232        iterator = Iter[str](["1", "2"])
233        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")
234        assert iterator.next() == Some("2")
235        assert iterator.next().is_none()
236        ```
237        """
238        try:
239            item = self.__next__()
240        except StopIteration:
241            # SAFETY: no items left.
242            return _option.nothing_unchecked()
243        return _option.Some(item)
244
245    def map(
246        self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem]
247    ) -> Iter[OtherItem]:
248        """Maps each item in the iterator to its predicated value.
249
250        Example
251        -------
252        ```py
253        iterator = Iter(["1", "2", "3"]).map(lambda value: int(value))
254
255        # <Iter([1, 2, 3])>
256        for item in iterator:
257            assert isinstance(item, int)
258        ```
259
260        Parameters
261        ----------
262        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], Item]`
263            The function to map each item in the iterator to its predicated value.
264        """
265        return Iter(predicate(item) for item in self._items)
266
267    def take(self, n: int) -> Iter[Item]:
268        """Take the first number of items until the number of items are yielded or
269        the end of the iterator is reached.
270
271        Example
272        -------
273        ```py
274        iterator = Iter(['c', 'x', 'y'])
275        for mode in iterator.take(2):
276            assert mode in ['c', 'x']
277        # <Iter(['c', 'x'])>
278        ```
279
280        Parameters
281        ----------
282        n: `int`
283            The number of items to take.
284        """
285        return Iter(itertools.islice(self._items, n))
286
287    def take_while(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Iter[Item]:
288        """Yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `True`.
289
290        Example
291        -------
292        ```py
293        iterator = Iter(['VIP', 'Regular', 'Guard'])
294        for membership in iterator.take_while(lambda m: m is 'VIP'):
295            print(membership)
296
297        # VIP
298        ```
299
300        Parameters
301        ----------
302        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
303            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.
304
305        Raises
306        ------
307        `StopIteration`
308            If no elements are left in the iterator.
309        """
310        return Iter(itertools.takewhile(predicate, self._items))
311
312    def drop_while(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Iter[Item]:
313        """Yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `False`.
314
315        Example
316        -------
317        ```py
318        iterator = Iter(['VIP', 'Regular', 'Guard'])
319        for membership in iterator.drop_while(lambda m: m is not 'VIP'):
320            print(membership)
321
322        # Regular
323        # Guard
324        ```
325
326        Parameters
327        ----------
328        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
329            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.
330
331        Raises
332        ------
333        `StopIteration`
334            If no elements are left in the iterator.
335        """
336        return Iter(itertools.dropwhile(predicate, self._items))
337
338    def filter(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Iter[Item]:
339        """Filters the iterator to only yield items that match the predicate.
340
341        Example
342        -------
343        ```py
344        places = Iter(['London', 'Paris', 'Los Angeles'])
345        for place in places.filter(lambda place: place.startswith('L')):
346            print(place)
347
348        # London
349        # Los Angeles
350        ```
351        """
352        return Iter(item for item in self._items if predicate(item))
353
354    def skip(self, n: int) -> Iter[Item]:
355        """Skips the first number of items in the iterator.
356
357        Example
358        -------
359        ```py
360        iterator = Iter([MembershipType.STEAM, MembershipType.XBOX, MembershipType.STADIA])
361        for platform in iterator.skip(1):
362            print(platform)
363        # Skip the first item in the iterator.
364        # <Iter([MembershipType.XBOX, MembershipType.STADIA])>
365        ```
366        """
367        return Iter(itertools.islice(self._items, n, None))

369    def zip(
370        self, other: collections.Iterable[OtherItem]
371    ) -> Iter[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]:
372        """Zips the iterator with another iterable.
373
374        Example
375        -------
376        ```py
377        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
378        for item, other_item in iterator.zip([4, 5, 6]):
379            assert item == other_item
380        <Iter([(1, 4), (2, 5), (3, 6)])>
381        ```
382

386            The iterable to zip with.
387
388        Returns
389        -------
390        `Iter[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]`
391            The zipped iterator.
392
393        Raises
394        ------
395        `StopIteration`
396            If no elements are left in the iterator.
397        """
398        return Iter(zip(self._items, other))

400    def all(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:
401        """Return `True` if all items in the iterator match the predicate.
402
403        Example
404        -------
405        ```py
406        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
407        while iterator.all(lambda item: isinstance(item, int)):
408            print("Still all integers")
409            continue
410            # Still all integers
411        ```
412
413        Parameters
414        ----------
415        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
416            The function to test each item in the iterator.
417
418        Raises
419        ------
420        `StopIteration`
421            If no elements are left in the iterator.
422        """
423        return all(predicate(item) for item in self._items)

425    def any(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:
426        """`True` if any items in the iterator match the predicate.

433            print("At least one item is an int.")

441

449    def sort(
450        self,
451        *,

453        reverse: bool = False,

456
457        Example

482    def first(self) -> Option[Item]:
483        """Returns the first item in the iterator.

500        """Returns the last item in the iterator.
501
502        Example

507        ```

511        `StopIteration`
512        If no elements are left in the iterator.

514        return self.reversed().first()

516    def reversed(self) -> Iter[Item]:
517        """Returns a new iterator that yields the items in the iterator in reverse order.
518
519        Example
520        -------
521        ```py
522        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
523        for item in iterator.reversed():
524            print(item)
525        # 7
526        # 6
527        # 1
528        # 3
529        ```
530
531        Raises
532        ------
533        `StopIteration`
534            If no elements are left in the iterator.
535        """
536        return Iter(reversed(self.collect()))

538    def count(self) -> int:
539        """Return the count of elements in memory this iterator has.
540
541        Example
542        -------
543        ```py
544        it = Iter(range(3))
545        assert it.count() == 3
546        ```
547        """
548        count = 0
549        for _ in self:
550            count += 1
551
552        return count

554    def union(self, other: Iter[Item]) -> Iter[Item]:
555        """Returns a new iterator that yields all items from both iterators.
556
557        Example
558        -------
559        ```py
560        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
561        other = Iter([4, 5, 6])
562        for item in iterator.union(other):
563            print(item)
564        # 1
565        # 2
566        # 3
567        # 4
568        # 5
569        # 6
570        ```
571
572        Parameters
573        ----------
574        other: `Iter[Item]`
575            The iterable to union with.
576
577        Raises
578        ------
579        `StopIteration`
580            If no elements are left in the iterator.
581        """
582        return Iter(itertools.chain(self._items, other))

584    def for_each(self, func: collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]) -> None:
585        """Calls `func` on each item in the iterator.
586
587        Example
588        -------
589        ```py
590        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
591        iterator.for_each(lambda item: print(item))
592        # 1
593        # 2
594        # 3
595        ```
596
597        Parameters
598        ----------
599        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]`
600            The function to call on each item in the iterator.
601        """
602        for item in self._items:
603            func(item)

605    async def async_for_each(
606        self,
607        func: collections.Callable[
608            [Item], collections.Coroutine[None, typing.Any, OtherItem]
609        ],
610    ) -> _result.Result[collections.Sequence[OtherItem], futures.SpawnErr]:
611        """Calls the async function on each item in the iterator concurrently.
612
613        Example
614        -------
615        ```py
616        async def create_user(username: str) -> None:
617            async with aiohttp.request("POST", f'.../{username}') as r:
618                return await r.json()
619
620        async def main():
621            users = sain.into_iter(["danny", "legalia"])
622            results = await users.async_for_each(lambda username: create_user(username))
623            for k, v in results.unwrap().items():
624                ...
625        ```
626
627        Parameters
628        ----------
629        func: `Callable[[Item], Coroutine[None, Any, Any]]`
630            The async function to call on each item in the iterator.
631        """
632        return await futures.spawn(*(func(item) for item in self._items))

634    def enumerate(self, *, start: int = 0) -> Iter[tuple[int, Item]]:
635        """Returns a new iterator that yields tuples of the index and item.
636
637        Example
638        -------
639        ```py
640        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
641        for index, item in iterator.enumerate():
642            print(index, item)
643        # 0, 1
644        # 1, 2
645        # 2, 3
646        ```
647
648        Raises
649        ------
650        `StopIteration`
651            If no elements are left in the iterator.
652        """
653        return Iter(enumerate(self._items, start=start))

655    def _ok(self) -> typing.NoReturn:
656        raise StopIteration("No more items in the iterator.") from None

658    def __getitem__(self, index: int) -> Option[Item]:
659        try:
660            return self.skip(index).first()
661        except IndexError:
662            self._ok()

666        raise NotImplementedError(

691    def __next__(self) -> Item:
692        try:
693            item = next(self._items)

a lazy, in-memory functional iterator.

This is similar to Rust Iterator trait which iterables can build from this via sain.iter() method.

Example
iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
# Limit the results to 2.
for item in iterator.take(2):
    print(item)
# 1
# 2

# Filter the results.
for item in iterator.filter(lambda item: item > 1):
    print(item)
    print(iterator.count())
# 2
# 3
# 3

# Indexing is supported.
print(iterator[0])
# 1

230        -------
231        ```py

233        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")

235        assert iterator.next().is_none()
236        ```
237        """
238        try:
239            item = self.__next__()
240        except StopIteration:
241            # SAFETY: no items left.
242            return _option.nothing_unchecked()

def deprecated( *, since: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, removed_in: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, use_instead: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, hint: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None) -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
152def deprecated(
153    *,
154    since: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
155    removed_in: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
156    use_instead: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
157    hint: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
158) -> collections.Callable[
159    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
160    collections.Callable[P, U],
161]:
162    """A decorator that marks a function as deprecated.
163
164    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
165
166    Example
167    -------
168    ```py
169    from sain import deprecated
170
171    @deprecated(
172        since = "1.0.0",
173        removed_in ="3.0.0",
174        use_instead = "UserImpl()",
175        hint = "Hint for ux."
176    )
177    class User:
178        ...
179
180    user = User() # This will cause a warning at runtime.
181    ```
182
183    Parameters
184    ----------
185    since : `str`
186        The version that the function was deprecated.
187    removed_in : `str | None`
188        If provided, It will log when will the object will be removed in.
189    use_instead : `str | None`
190        If provided, This should be the alternative object name that should be used instead.
191    hint: `str`
192        An optional hint for the user.
193    """
194
195    def _create_message(obj: typing.Any) -> str:
196        msg = f"{_obj_type(obj)} `{obj.__module__}.{obj.__name__}` is deprecated."
197
198        if since is not None:
199            msg += f" since {since}."
200
201        if removed_in:
202            msg += f" Scheduled for removal in `{removed_in}`."
203
204        if use_instead is not None:
205            msg += f" Use `{use_instead}` instead."
206
207        if hint:
208            msg += f" Hint: {hint}"
209        return msg
210
211    def decorator(func: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
212        message = _create_message(func)
213
214        @functools.wraps(func)
215        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
216            _warn(message)
217            return func(*args, **kwargs)
218
219        # idk why pyright doesn't know the type of wrapper.
220        m = f"\n# Warning ⚠️\n{message}."
221        if wrapper.__doc__:
222            # append this message to an existing document.
223            wrapper.__doc__ = inspect.cleandoc(wrapper.__doc__) + f"{m}"
224        else:
225            wrapper.__doc__ = m
226        return wrapper
227
228    return decorator

A decorator that marks a function as deprecated.

An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.

Example
from sain import deprecated

@deprecated(
    since = "1.0.0",
    removed_in ="3.0.0",
    use_instead = "UserImpl()",
    hint = "Hint for ux."
)
class User:
    ...

user = User() # This will cause a warning at runtime.
Parameters
  • since (str): The version that the function was deprecated.
  • removed_in (str | None): If provided, It will log when will the object will be removed in.
  • use_instead (str | None): If provided, This should be the alternative object name that should be used instead.
  • hint (str): An optional hint for the user.
def unimplemented( *, message: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, available_in: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None) -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
252def unimplemented(
253    *,
254    message: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
255    available_in: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
256) -> collections.Callable[
257    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
258    collections.Callable[P, U],
259]:
260    """A decorator that marks an object as unimplemented.
261
262    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
263
264    Example
265    -------
266    ```py
267    from sain import unimplemented
268
269    @unimplemented("User object is not implemented yet.")

271        ...
272    ```
273
274    Parameters
275    ----------
276    message : `str | None`
277        An optional message to be displayed when the function is called. Otherwise default message will be used.
278    available_in : `str | None`
279        If provided, This will be shown as what release this object be implemented.
280    """
281
282    def _create_message(obj: typing.Any) -> str:
283        msg = (
284            message
285            or f"{_obj_type(obj)} `{obj.__module__}.{obj.__name__}` is not yet implemented."
286        )  # noqa: W503
287
288        if available_in:
289            msg += f" Available in `{available_in}`."
290        return msg
291
292    def decorator(obj: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
293        message = _create_message(obj)
294
295        @functools.wraps(obj)
296        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
297            _warn(message)
298            return obj(*args, **kwargs)
299
300        # idk why pyright doesn't know the type of wrapper.
301        m = f"\n# Warning ⚠️\n{message}."
302        if wrapper.__doc__:
303            # append this message to an existing document.
304            wrapper.__doc__ = inspect.cleandoc(wrapper.__doc__) + f"{m}"
305        else:
306            wrapper.__doc__ = m
307        return wrapper
308
309    return decorator

A decorator that marks an object as unimplemented.

An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.

Example
from sain import unimplemented

@unimplemented("User object is not implemented yet.")
class User:
    ...
Parameters
  • message (str | None): An optional message to be displayed when the function is called. Otherwise default message will be used.
  • available_in (str | None): If provided, This will be shown as what release this object be implemented.
def doc( path: 'Read') -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
312def doc(
313    path: Read,
314) -> collections.Callable[
315    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
316    collections.Callable[P, U],
317]:
318    """Set `path` to be the object's documentation.
319
320    Example
321    -------
322    ```py
323    from sain import doc
324    from pathlib import Path
325
326    @doc(Path("../README.md"))
327    class User:
328
329        @doc("bool.html")
330        def bool_docs() -> None:
331            ...
332    ```
333
334    Parameters
335    ----------
336    path: `type[int] | type[str] | type[bytes] | type[PathLike[str]] | type[PathLike[bytes]]`
337        The path to read the content from.
338    """
339
340    def decorator(f: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
341        with open(path, "r") as file:
342            f.__doc__ = file.read()
343
344        @functools.wraps(f)
345        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
346            return f(*args, **kwargs)
347
348        return wrapper
349
350    return decorator

138    def is_ok(self) -> typing.Literal[True]:
139        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `False` if it an `Err`.
140
141        Example
142        -------
143        ```py
144        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
145        assert value.is_ok() == True
146        ```
147        """
148        return True
149
150    def is_ok_and(self, f: F[T, bool]) -> bool:
151        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `f()` returns True..
152
153        Example
154        -------
155        ```py
156        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
157

159        # True
160        ```

257    def unwrap_err(self) -> typing.NoReturn:
258        """Return the contained `Err` value, Raising if it was `Ok`.

260        Example

267        err.unwrap_err() == None
268        # True
269        ```

277    def ok(self) -> Option[T]:

307    def inspect(self, f: F[T, typing.Any]) -> None:

344    def map(self, f: F[T, U], /) -> Ok[U]:
345        """Map `Ok[T]` to `Ok[U]` by applying a function to `T`, Leaving `Err` untouched.
346
347        Example
348        -------
349        ```py
350        ok: Result[str, int] = Ok("1")
351        ok.map(lambda c: int(c) + 1) # Ok(2)
352
353        err: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
354        err.map(str.upper) # Err(0)
355        ```
356        """
357        return Ok(f(self._inner))
358
359    def map_or(self, f: F[T, U], default: U, /) -> U:
360        """Returns the provided default value if `Err`,
361
362        Otherwise extracts the `Ok` value and maps it to `f()`
363
364        Example
365        -------
366        ```py
367        x: Result[str, str] = Ok("foo")
368        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 3
369
370        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
371        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 42
372        ```
373        """
374        return f(self._inner)
375
376    def map_or_else(self, f: F[T, U], default: F[E, U], /) -> U:
377        """Returns the provided default value from a function if `Err`,
378
379        Otherwise extracts the `Ok` value and maps it to `f()`
380
381        Example
382        -------
383        ```py
384        x: Result[str, str] = Ok("four")
385        assert x.map_or_else(
386            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
387            lambda err: len(err)
388        ) == 8
389
390        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
391        assert x.map_or_else(
392            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
393            lambda err: len(err)
394        ) == 3
395        ```
396        """
397        return f(self._inner)
398
399    def map_err(self, f: F[E, U], /) -> Self:
400        """Maps a `Result[T, E]` to `Result[T, U]`, leaving `OK[T]` untouched.
401
402        Example
403        -------
404        ```py
405        x: Result[str, int] = Ok("blue")
406        x.map_err(lambda err: err + 1) # Ok("blue")
407
408        x: Result[str, int] = Err(5)
409        x.map_err(float) # Err(5.0)
410        ```
411        """
412        return self

418    def iter(self) -> _iter.Iter[T]:

431        ```
432        """
433        return self.__iter__()

436        return _iter.once(self._inner)

368        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 3
369
370        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
371        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 42
372        ```
373        """
374        return f(self._inner)

Returns the provided default value if Err,

Otherwise extracts the Ok value and maps it to f()

Example
x: Result[str, str] = Ok("foo")
assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 3

x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 42

376    def map_or_else(self, f: F[T, U], default: F[E, U], /) -> U:
377        """Returns the provided default value from a function if `Err`,
378

391        assert x.map_or_else(
392            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
393            lambda err: len(err)
394        ) == 3
395        ```
396        """
397        return f(self._inner)

399    def map_err(self, f: F[E, U], /) -> Self:

410        ```

@typing.final
class Vec(typing.Generic[~T]): 
 71@typing.final
 72class Vec(typing.Generic[T]):
 73    """A contiguous growable alternative to builtin `list` with extra functionalities.
 74
 75    When initializing a vec, it will not build the underlying list until the first element gets pushed.
 76    Which saves a little bit of memory.
 77
 78    Example
 79    -------
 80    ```py
 81    names = Vec()
 82
 83    names.push('foo')
 84    names.push('bar')
 85
 86    print(names) # ['foo', 'bar']
 87    assert names.len() == 2
 88    ```
 89
 90    Equality is supported.
 91
 92    ```py
 93    vec = Vec((1,2,3))
 94    vec == [1, 2, 3] and vec # True
 95    ```
 96    """
 97
 98    __slots__ = ("_ptr", "_capacity")
 99
100    @typing.overload
101    def __init__(self) -> None: ...
102
103    @typing.overload
104    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T]) -> None: ...
105
106    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T] | None = None) -> None:
107        """Initializes a new vec, This won't actually create the internal list until an element is appended into it.
108
109        Example
110        -------
111        ```py
112        names = Vec[str]()
113
114        names.push('foo')
115        names.push('bar')
116
117        assert names.len() == 2
118
119        # Initialize a vec from another iterable.
120        from_iter = Vec((1,2,3))
121        assert from_iter.len() == 3
122        ```
123        """
124
125        # We won't allocate to build the list here.
126        # Instead, On first push or fist indexed set
127        # we allocate if it was None.
128        self._ptr: list[T] | None = list(iterable) if iterable else None
129        self._capacity = 0
130
131    @classmethod
132    @macros.unstable()
133    def with_capacity(cls, capacity: int) -> Vec[T]:
134        """Create a new `Vec` with at least the specified capacity.
135
136        This vec will be able to hold `capacity` elements without pushing further if `len(vec) == capacity`.
137
138        Example
139        -------
140        ```py
141        vec = Vec.with_capacity(3)
142        assert vec.len() == 0 and vec.capacity() >= 3
143
144        vec.push(1)
145        vec.push(2)
146        vec.push(3)
147        print(vec.len()) # 3
148
149        # This won't push.
150        vec.push(4)
151        ```
152        """
153        v = Vec[T]()
154        v._capacity = capacity
155        return v
156
157    def boxed(self) -> collections.Collection[T]:
158        """Return an immutable tuple over this vector elements.
159
160        Example
161        -------
162        ```py
163        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
164
165        assert vec.boxed() == (1,2,3)
166        ```
167        """
168        return tuple(self)
169
170    def len(self) -> int:
171        """Return the number of elements in this vector.
172
173        Example
174        -------
175        ```py
176        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
177
178        assert vec.len() == 3
179        ```
180        """
181        return self.__len__()
182
183    @macros.unstable(reason="not unimplemented yet.")
184    def capacity(self) -> int:
185        """Return the capacity of this vector.
186
187        Example
188        -------
189        ```py
190        TODO
191        ```
192        """
193        return self._capacity
194
195    def iter(self) -> _iter.Iter[T]:
196        """Return an iterator over this vector elements.
197
198        Example
199        -------
200        ```py
201        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
202        iterator = vec.iter()
203
204        # Map each element to a str
205        for element in iterator.map(str):
206            print(element)
207        ```
208        """
209        return _iter.Iter(self)
210
211    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
212        """Returns true if the vector contains no elements."""
213        return self.len() == 0
214
215    def split_off(self, at: int) -> Vec[T]:
216        """Split the vector off at the specified position.
217
218        Example
219        -------
220        ```py
221        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
222        split = vec.split_off(1)
223
224        print(split, vec)  # [1], [2, 3]
225        ```
226        """
227        if at > self.len():
228            raise RuntimeError(
229                f"Index `at` ({at}) should be <= than len of vector ({self.len()}) "
230            ) from None
231
232        # Either the list is empty or uninit.
233        if not self._ptr:
234            return self
235
236        split = self[at : self.len()]
237        self._ptr = self._ptr[0:at]
238        return split
239
240    def split_first(self) -> _option.Option[tuple[T, collections.Sequence[T]]]:
241        """Split the first and rest elements of the vector, If empty, `Some[None]` is returned.
242
243        Example
244        -------
245        ```py
246        vec = vec(1, 2, 3)
247        split = vec.split_first()
248        assert split == Some((1, [2, 3]))
249
250        vec: Vec[int] = vec()
251        split = vec.split_first()
252        assert split == Some(None)
253        ```
254        """
255        if not self._ptr:
256            return _option.nothing_unchecked()
257
258        first, *rest = self._ptr
259        return _option.Some((first, rest))
260
261    def first(self) -> _option.Option[T]:
262        """Get the first element in this vec, returning `Some[None]` if there's none.
263
264        Example
265        -------
266        ```py
267        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
268        first = vec.first()
269        assert ~first == 1
270        ```
271        """
272        return self.get(0)
273
274    def truncate(self, size: int) -> None:
275        """Shortens the vec, keeping the first `size` elements and dropping the rest.
276
277        Example
278        -------
279        ```py
280        vec = vec(1,2,3)
281        vec.truncate(1)
282        assert vec == [1]
283        ```
284        """
285        if not self._ptr:
286            return
287
288        self._ptr = self._ptr[:size]
289
290    def retain(self, f: collections.Callable[[T], bool]) -> None:
291        """Remove elements from this vec while `f()` returns `True`.
292
293        In other words, filter this vector based on `f()`.
294
295        Example
296        -------
297        ```py
298        vec = vec(1, 2, 3)
299        vec.retain(lambda elem: elem > 1)
300
301        assert vec == [2, 3]
302        ```
303        """
304        if not self._ptr:
305            return
306
307        self._ptr = [e for e in self._ptr if f(e)]
308
309    ##########################
310    # * Builtin Operations *
311    ##########################
312
313    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
314        """Push an element at the end of the vector.
315
316        Example
317        ```py
318        vec = Vec()
319        vec.push(1)
320
321        assert vec == [1]
322        ```
323        """
324        if self._ptr is None:
325            self._ptr = []
326
327        self._ptr.append(item)
328
329    # For people how are used to calling list.append
330    append = push
331    """An alias for `Vec.push` method."""
332
333    def get(self, index: int) -> _option.Option[T]:
334        """Get the item at the given index, or `Some[None]` if its out of bounds.
335
336        Example
337        -------
338        ```py
339        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
340        vec.get(0) == Some(1)
341        vec.get(3) == Some(None)
342        ```
343        """
344        try:
345            return _option.Some(self.__getitem__(index))
346        except IndexError:
347            return _option.nothing_unchecked()
348
349    def insert(self, index: int, value: T) -> None:
350        """Insert an element at the position `index`.
351
352        Example
353        --------
354        ```py
355        vec = Vec((2, 3))
356        vec.insert(0, 1)
357        assert vec == [1, 2, 3]
358        ```
359        """
360        self.__setitem__(index, value)
361
362    def pop(self, index: int = -1) -> _option.Option[T]:
363        """Removes the last element from a vector and returns it, or `sain.Some(None)` if it is empty.
364
365        Example
366        -------
367        ```py
368        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
369        assert vec.pop() == Some(3)
370        assert vec == [1, 2]
371        ```
372        """
373        if not self._ptr:
374            return _option.nothing_unchecked()
375
376        return _option.Some(self._ptr.pop(index))
377
378    def remove(self, item: T) -> None:
379        """Remove `item` from this vector.
380
381        Example
382        -------
383        ```py
384        vec = Vector(('a', 'b', 'c'))
385        vec.remove('a')
386        assert vec == ['b', 'c']
387        ```
388        """
389        if not self._ptr:
390            return
391
392        self._ptr.remove(item)
393
394    def swap_remove(self, item: T) -> T:
395        """Remove the first appearance of `item` from this vector and return it.
396
397        Raises
398        ------
399        * `ValueError`: if `item` is not in this vector.
400        * `MemoryError`: if this vector hasn't allocated, Aka nothing has been pushed to it.
401
402        Example
403        -------
404        ```py
405        vec = Vector(('a', 'b', 'c'))
406        element = vec.remove('a')
407        assert vec == ['b', 'c'] and element == 'a'
408        ```
409        """
410        if self._ptr is None:
411            raise MemoryError("Vec is unallocated.") from None
412
413        try:
414            i = next(i for i in self._ptr if i == item)
415        except StopIteration:
416            raise ValueError(f"Item `{item}` not in list") from None
417
418        self.remove(i)
419        return i
420
421    def extend(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T]) -> None:
422        """Extend this vector from another iterable.
423
424        Example
425        -------
426        ```py
427        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
428        vec.extend((4, 5, 6))
429
430        assert vec == [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
431        ```
432        """
433        if not self._ptr:
434            return
435
436        self._ptr.extend(iterable)
437
438    def copy(self) -> Vec[T]:
439        """Create a vector that copies all of its elements and place it into the new one.
440
441        If the vector hasn't been allocated, `self` is returned.
442
443        Example
444        -------
445        ```py
446        original = Vec((1,2,3))
447        copy = original.copy()
448        copy.push(4)
449
450        print(original) # [1, 2, 3]
451        ```
452        """
453        return Vec(self._ptr[:]) if self._ptr is not None else self
454
455    def clear(self) -> None:
456        """Clear all elements of this vector.
457
458        Example
459        -------
460        ```py
461        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
462        vec.clear()
463        assert vec.len() == 0
464        ```
465        """
466        if not self._ptr:
467            return
468
469        self._ptr.clear()
470
471    def __len__(self) -> int:
472        return len(self._ptr) if self._ptr else 0
473
474    def __setitem__(self, index: int, value: T):
475        if self._ptr is None:
476            self._ptr = []
477
478        self._ptr[index] = value
479
480    @typing.overload
481    def __getitem__(self, index: slice) -> Vec[T]: ...

483    @typing.overload
484    def __getitem__(self, index: int) -> T: ...
485
486    def __getitem__(self, index: int | slice) -> T | Vec[T]:
487        if not self._ptr:
488            raise IndexError("Index out of range")
489
490        if isinstance(index, slice):
491            return self.__class__(self._ptr[index])
492
493        return self._ptr[index]
494
495    def __delitem__(self, index: int) -> None:
496        if not self._ptr:
497            return
498
499        del self._ptr[index]
500
501    def __contains__(self, element: T) -> bool:
502        return element in self._ptr if self._ptr else False
503
504    def __iter__(self) -> collections.Iterator[T]:
505        if self._ptr is None:
506            return iter(())
507
508        return self._ptr.__iter__()
509
510    def __repr__(self) -> str:
511        return "[]" if not self._ptr else repr(self._ptr)
512
513    def __eq__(self, other: object) -> bool:
514        if not self._ptr:
515            return False
516
517        if isinstance(other, Vec):
518            return self._ptr == other._ptr
519        if isinstance(other, (collections.Iterable, collections.MutableSequence)):
520            return list(other) == self._ptr
521
522        return NotImplemented
523
524    def __ne__(self, other: object) -> bool:
525        return not self.__eq__(other)
526
527    def __le__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
528        if not self._ptr:
529            return False
530        return self._ptr <= list(other)
531
532    def __ge__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
533        if not self._ptr:
534            return False
535
536        return self._ptr >= list(other)
537
538    def __lt__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
539        if not self._ptr:
540            return False
541
542        return self._ptr < list(other)
543
544    def __gt__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
545        if not self._ptr:
546            return False
547
548        return self._ptr > list(other)
549
550    def __bool__(self) -> bool:
551        return bool(self._ptr)

A contiguous growable alternative to builtin list with extra functionalities.

When initializing a vec, it will not build the underlying list until the first element gets pushed. Which saves a little bit of memory.

Example
names = Vec()

names.push('foo')
names.push('bar')

print(names) # ['foo', 'bar']
assert names.len() == 2

Equality is supported.

vec = Vec((1,2,3))
vec == [1, 2, 3] and vec # True
Vec(iterable: collections.abc.Iterable[~T] | None = None) 
106    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T] | None = None) -> None:
107        """Initializes a new vec, This won't actually create the internal list until an element is appended into it.
108
109        Example
110        -------
111        ```py
112        names = Vec[str]()
113
114        names.push('foo')
115        names.push('bar')
116
117        assert names.len() == 2
118
119        # Initialize a vec from another iterable.
120        from_iter = Vec((1,2,3))
121        assert from_iter.len() == 3
122        ```
123        """
124
125        # We won't allocate to build the list here.
126        # Instead, On first push or fist indexed set
127        # we allocate if it was None.
128        self._ptr: list[T] | None = list(iterable) if iterable else None
129        self._capacity = 0

def split_off(self, at: int) -> Vec[~T]: 
215    def split_off(self, at: int) -> Vec[T]:
216        """Split the vector off at the specified position.
217
218        Example
219        -------
220        ```py
221        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
222        split = vec.split_off(1)

229                f"Index `at` ({at}) should be <= than len of vector ({self.len()}) "
230            ) from None

234            return self

def swap_remove(self, item: ~T) -> ~T: 
394    def swap_remove(self, item: T) -> T:
395        """Remove the first appearance of `item` from this vector and return it.
396
397        Raises
398        ------
399        * `ValueError`: if `item` is not in this vector.
400        * `MemoryError`: if this vector hasn't allocated, Aka nothing has been pushed to it.
401
402        Example
403        -------
404        ```py
405        vec = Vector(('a', 'b', 'c'))
406        element = vec.remove('a')
407        assert vec == ['b', 'c'] and element == 'a'
408        ```
409        """
410        if self._ptr is None:
411            raise MemoryError("Vec is unallocated.") from None
412
413        try:
414            i = next(i for i in self._ptr if i == item)
415        except StopIteration:
416            raise ValueError(f"Item `{item}` not in list") from None
417
418        self.remove(i)
419        return i

Remove the first appearance of item from this vector and return it.

class Error(typing.Protocol): 
 56@typing.runtime_checkable
 57class Error(typing.Protocol):
 58    """`Error` is an interface usually used for values that returns `sain.Result[T, E]`
 59
 60    where `E` is an implementation of this interface.
 61
 62    Example
 63    -------
 64    ```py
 65    class PathError(Error):
 66        # The base message of this error. It will be shown when printing the error.
 67        def __init__(self, message: str = "...") -> None:
 68            super().__init__(message)
 69
 70        def source(self) -> _option.Option[type[Error]]:
 71            # If this error was derived from another error, It can be returned here.
 72            # For an example, This PathError might be derived from `IOError`
 73            # where `IOError` is also derived from `Error`.
 74            return Some(IOError)
 75
 76        def description(self) -> str:
 77            return "A very detailed description about the error."
 78
 79    def read(path: str) -> Result[str, Error]:
 80        try:
 81            with open(path, "r") as file:
 82                return Ok(file.read())
 83
 84        # FileNotFoundError is a subclass of IOError
 85        except (FileNotFoundError, IOError) as e:
 86            return Err(PathError(str(e)))
 87
 88    match read("/dev/null"):
 89        case Ok(content):
 90            ...
 91        case Err(err):
 92            print(err)
 93    ```
 94    """
 95
 96    __slots__ = ("message",)
 97
 98    def __init__(self, message: str = "") -> None:
 99        self.message = message
100
101    def source(self) -> _option.Option[type[Error]]:
102        """The source of this error, if any."""
103        return _option.nothing_unchecked()
104
105    def description(self) -> str:
106        """Context for this error."""
107        return ""
108
109    def __repr__(self) -> str:
110        source = None if (src := self.source()).is_none() else src
111        return (
112            f'{type(self).__qualname__}(message: "{self.message}, source: {source!r})'
113        )
114
115    def __str__(self) -> str:
116        return self.message
117
118    # An error is always falsy.
119    def __bool__(self) -> typing.Literal[False]:
120        return False

Error is an interface usually used for values that returns sain.Result[T, E]

where E is an implementation of this interface.

Example
class PathError(Error):
    # The base message of this error. It will be shown when printing the error.
    def __init__(self, message: str = "...") -> None:
        super().__init__(message)

    def source(self) -> _option.Option[type[Error]]:
        # If this error was derived from another error, It can be returned here.
        # For an example, This PathError might be derived from `IOError`
        # where `IOError` is also derived from `Error`.
        return Some(IOError)

1430def _no_init_or_replace_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
1431    cls = type(self)
1432
1433    if cls._is_protocol:
1434        raise TypeError('Protocols cannot be instantiated')
1435
1436    # Already using a custom `__init__`. No need to calculate correct
1437    # `__init__` to call. This can lead to RecursionError. See bpo-45121.
1438    if cls.__init__ is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1439        return
1440
1441    # Initially, `__init__` of a protocol subclass is set to `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1442    # The first instantiation of the subclass will call `_no_init_or_replace_init` which
1443    # searches for a proper new `__init__` in the MRO. The new `__init__`
1444    # replaces the subclass' old `__init__` (ie `_no_init_or_replace_init`). Subsequent
1445    # instantiation of the protocol subclass will thus use the new
1446    # `__init__` and no longer call `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1447    for base in cls.__mro__:
1448        init = base.__dict__.get('__init__', _no_init_or_replace_init)
1449        if init is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1450            cls.__init__ = init
1451            break
1452    else:
1453        # should not happen
1454        cls.__init__ = object.__init__
1455
1456    cls.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
message
